channel.description: The source control system within Visual Studio Team System has a very powerful security model. One of the nice things is that if a user does not have read permissions on one of the objects in a tree, then that...
channel.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by Rein+00:00
item.description: Why isn't there an option to copy the inherited permissions when you stop inheriting? NTFS permissions does exactly that.
item.dc:creator: Rein

item.title: Comment by Martin+00:00
item.description: Time, I guess :-) But you are right - that would be good from a usability point of view.
item.dc:creator: Martin

item.title: Comment by James Manning+00:00
item.description:
Couple things to note:
1) As long as you know the path ($/foo/bar) and you are an admin, you can use the command-line (in Beta 3 and final) to change the permissions still (granting yourself Read again, for instance)
2) We've made a fix so that admins will see such items in the UI regardless of whether they currently have Read permission or not, for exactly this reason.
I'm not sure about the copying of inherited permissions - it seems like a good idea, and it may just be an oversight, I've forwarded it along to the responsible dev to find out.
item.dc:creator: James Manning

item.title: Comment by James Manning+00:00
item.description: On the copy-inherited-permissions-when-you-stop-inheriting, I've checked and it appears it's just an oversight on our part, unfortunately. It's not likely to make the bar given how close we are to shipping, but it's likely to make V2.
item.dc:creator: James Manning

item.title: Comment by James Manning+00:00
item.description:
Just to confirm, we've decided to postpone the copy inherited permissions, but it's a filed bug now and it'll be considered (and should be likely) for V2.
Thanks, Rein!
item.dc:creator: James Manning
